motivation_5: NA
2025_promote_OS: NA
barriers_other: Practising open science strongly depends on the research discipline. Researchers must determine themselves how open science can be used to improve their research. Advising researchers on Open Access or on publishing their data means little to them.
support_researchers: Open Science is usually perceived as something centered around library functions, e.g., open access for articles and publishing research data. That researchers share research results during their research with colleagues is considered basic/good research practice and not 'open science'.
uni_support_other: Foster policies, communities of practice, align incentives (recognition & rewards), offer robust tools on the (inter)national or discipline-level. Open research is not anchored in a university, it must be anchored in the discipline.
oscl_support_other: Starter kits, success stories, networks, ambassadors, feeding management about what researchers need and run into.
RR_ideal_support:
Integrate open science in progress / career assessment. Assess not only papers, grants, citations, downloads, etc. Reward efforts that continue after a project has ended, e.g., that lead to open source projects, continued public engagement, etc.
Approach this by discipline/faculty: avoid one approach for all - recognize that open data or preprints are easier is some areas than in others.
good_practice_exampl: Utrecht University has adopted Open Science as a strategic area.

barriers_2: Lack of training on how to practice Open Science

barriers_12_TEXT: The restrictiveness -- and complexity -- of the contractual rules on open access that commercial publishers impose on authors.
training_need:
'-- How to deal with, and avoid, the restrictions (including fees) that commercial publishers impose on publishing in open access. 
-- Possibilities for making more of my teaching and educational materials publicly accessible for everyone.
more_OS_1: More policies that make Open Science practices required
more_OS_5: More supporting infrastructure that makes it possible to practice Open Science
more_OS_7_TEXT: A central Helpdesk (which can be contacted by phone, email, etc.) at Leiden University where I can call and ask advice and assistance: on dealing with publishers who restrict open access of my publications, and on possibilities (and places) for putting more of my teaching and teaching materials in open access.
2025_promote_OS: Yes, this is my motivation for doing so:
2025_promote_OS_2_TEXT: Among some colleagues I promote publishing in open access (although I am not able to support them in this. The reason is that many of them (inside and outside Leiden University) are hardly aware of the importance of open access.
new2025_OER:
Impact in society (including in law) is my main motivation to do research and to teach, and therefore also for publishing in open access and for aiming to make my teaching and teaching materials publicly accessible.
As regards open education, the main obstacle seems to be that Leiden University does not seem to have a system (like LUCRIS & the Repository) for making unpublished teaching materials and/or recorded lectures publicly accessible: each year I am asked to upload my research publications in LUCRIS, but I am never asked to upload relevant unpublished teaching materials/recordings.
uni_support:
It would help if the university would provide funding to pay the fees that many commercial publishers impose on authors who want to publish in open access. As indicated above, a Helpdesk for the whole of Leiden University (reachable by phone, email, etc.) would be helpful, for example in how to deal with restrictive publishers (including fee-imposing publishers, and publishers that do not even allow open access for a fee). Open access issues with publishers often arise on unexpected days and often need to be resolved within a few days -- therefore a Helpdesk would be much more useful than training courses.
(Some background info: In my field (law) it are often the publishers who invite researchers to publish something; researchers can often not afford to reject such invitations, and are therefore often bound by the restrictive rules of the publishers.)
oscl_support:
The two cited main goals of OSCL seem oddly restrictive. Much more than peer-to-peer learning is required: the academic leaders of Faculties and Institutes should ask their researchers each year not only to upload all their publications in LUCRIS, but they should then also point out how to get those publications in (better) open access, and simultaneously encourage and assist these researchers and also all teachers in how to put more of their unpublished research and teaching materials/recordings in open access, including through a LUCRIS-like system for teaching materials and recordings.
And the bottom-up perspective should not just help policymakers, but especially the researchers and teachers themselves: through a LUCRIS-like system (including annual reminders, tips and encouragements) for making unpublished results of teaching or research publicly accessible, and through a Helpdesk (see above) that can help a researcher or teacher in real-time in solving (legal, financial, technical) open access issues with publishers etc.
RR_ideal: As regards the required minimum number of publications by a researcher: three open access publications should count as four publications.
new2025_methods: Both qualitative and quantitative methods equally

barriers_other: i have no formal role in advising on this topic
support_researchers: I advised mostly on open education, and teachers often see the benefit and logic of making/using open education material, but teachers find it hard to make time. I usually advised them to start small (e.g. use open access literature instead of paywalled literature) and slowly replace figures/pictures from copyrighted study books with OpenEd alternatives. And to collaborate within your department/national/international expert community. And to ask advise from the university library for technical support in making collections of suitable material (edusources etc).
uni_support_other:
Keep communicating about the benefits of open Science, like increased quality of research by open peer review of research proposals / open data sets.
Establish team prizes for teachers who actively contribute as a community to open education.
Make open education and science part of GROW topics on which someone can be recognised, and allowed to spend paid time on.

recognition/paid time e.g. for working on open educational material.
team prizes for collaborative projects of teachers on open educational material

barriers_other: It's not so commonplace to make science open yet, so there is a lack of answers to common questions, like preferred licenses for source code or "templates" for datasets. That means more work is required to show what it means to "do" Open Science in projects.
support_researchers: People I have worked with are generally supportive of Open Science, but sharing all data from the start is too open.
uni_support_other: Highlight good examples for all disciplines and types of research and guide people on their paths to follow those examples.
oscl_support_other: Be the cool club that everyone wants to be part of :)
RR_ideal_support:
Award OpenBadges (or Edubadges) as a visual and machine actionable recognition. Awardees can choose to show them off. They should not be hard to earn, yet they should prove the awardee actually did practice some Open Science thing.

Also, to compensate for the work of practicing Open Science, some work pressure should be taken away: provide assistance for administrative tasks, carry the person's bag for one morning. Practicing Open Science is investing a little extra to save money later, so that money can be used to help with more boring tasks.

motivation_5: NA
2025_promote_OS: NA
barriers_other: The line between expertise and activism. What I think would be best, may require lots of work and attention by authors that they can't afford to dedicate.
support_researchers: Usually well - at least it makes people (re)consider, explicate and argue practices they've adopted implicitly and intuitively. Open Science imo starts with having conversations about why we do things the way we do them. :)
uni_support_other:
Foster and support a community on OS, which means giving people official positions - paid time allotted and all! - to work on community engagement, shared materials (how-to's, onboarding, e-learning etc) and championing good examples, especially across faculties (interdisciplinary) and with formal embedding in governance. fAiM-teams are how, in many cases, focused more on career trajectories (Erkennen & Waarderen) than on Open Science. 
OSCL does great work, but for all involved it comes 'extra'.
oscl_support_other: I understand the researcher's perspective to be central, but more exchange with relevant support staff could be useful (on both sides, so working towards goal-2).
RR_ideal_support:
Hall of Fame? Digital of course. Just the chance to showcase your work. 
Annual awards? Ceremonial, no great prizes but basically free pizza for the team, or so. Also great to find new 'champions' who can get the conversation going. I liked the LUMC 'preprint cake', where authors who submitted a preprint can win a cake in a monthly raffle.
